title: Delfo Cabrera
text:
Delfo Cabrera Gómez (April 2, 1919 – August 2, 1981) was an <a href="Argentine">Argentine</a> <a href="Athletics%20%28sport%29">athlete</a>, winner of the <a href="Marathon%20%28sport%29">marathon race</a> at the <a href="1948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948 Summer Olympics</a> in one of the most dramatic finishes in athletics history.
Biography.
Born in <a href="Armstrong%2C%20Santa%20Fe">Armstrong</a>, <a href="Santa%20Fe%20Province">Santa Fe Province</a>, Delfo played <a href="Football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> as a youth, but decided to turn to athletics after <a href="Juan%20Carlos%20Zabala">Juan Carlos Zabala</a>'s triumph at the <a href="1932%20Summer%20Olympics">1932 Summer Olympics</a>.
He moved to <a href="Buenos%20Aires">Buenos Aires</a> in 1938 and began training in <a href="San%20Lorenzo%20de%20Almagro">San Lorenzo de Almagro</a> under <a href="Francisco%20Mura">Francisco Mura</a>. In the same year, he won his first national championships title (in 5000 m). Over the years he would win 9 more titles, but none of them in marathon.
Delfo served in the army during the <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> where he met <a href="Juan%20Per%C3%B3n">Juan Perón</a>. After the war, being a friend of Perón, he was active member of the <a href="Justicialist%20Party">Justicialist Party</a>. 
The <a href="London">London</a> <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a> was Cabrera's first major international competition. <a href="Etienne%20Gailly">Etienne Gailly</a> from <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a> dominated the marathon race most of the way and until almost the very last moments. He was the first to enter the stadium, but with 400 m to go, Gailly fell down, exhausted, got up and fell again. It was like <a href="Dorando%20Pietri">Dorando Pietri</a>'s dramatic finish 40 years before. Cabrera and <a href="Tom%20Richards%20%28athlete%29">Tom Richards</a> of <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> managed to pass the staggering Gailly, Delfo winning 16.0 <a href="second">second</a>s ahead of Richards.
For 64 years, the victory remained the last Argentinian gold medal in an individual competition, until the victory of <a href="Sebasti%C3%A1n%20Crismanich">Sebastián Crismanich</a> in <a href="taekwondo">taekwondo</a> in the <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012 games</a>.
Cabrera also participated in the <a href="1952%20Summer%20Olympics">1952 Summer Olympics</a> and was the flag bearer for <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a> at the opening ceremony; he finished in sixth place in the marathon, which was won by <a href="Emil%20Z%C3%A1topek">Emil Zátopek</a>. Cabrera ended his athletics career after finishing sixth at the 1954 <a href="Boston%20Marathon">Boston Marathon</a>. After that he taught <a href="physical%20education">physical education</a> in several schools.
Delfo died in a car accident near the town of <a href="Alberti%2C%20Buenos%20Aires">Alberti</a>, <a href="Buenos%20Aires%20province">Buenos Aires province</a>, when driving back to Buenos Aires from a reception in his honour at <a href="Lincoln%2C%20Buenos%20Aires">Lincoln</a>.
